factoid: Prince Andrew thought 'All is over'.
A cold sweat broke out on Prince Andrew's forehead.
Prince Andrew went to the cot in confusion.
Prince Andrew was sure he would find the cot empty.
Prince Andrew was sure the nurse had been hiding the dead baby.
Prince Andrew drew the curtain aside.
Prince Andrew's frightened, restless eyes could not find the baby for some time.
Prince Andrew saw the baby.
The baby was a rosy boy.
The baby tossed about until he lay across the bed.
The baby's head was lower than the pillow.
The baby was smacking his lips in his sleep.
The baby was breathing evenly.
Prince Andrew was glad to find the boy.
Prince Andrew felt as if he had already lost the boy.
Prince Andrew bent over the boy.
Prince Andrew tried with his lips whether the child was still feverish.
The child's forehead was moist.
Prince Andrew touched the child's head with his hand.
The child's hair was wet.
The child had perspired profusely.
The child was not dead.
The crisis was over.
The child was convalescent.
Prince Andrew longed to snatch up the child.
Prince Andrew longed to squeeze the child.
Prince Andrew longed to hold the child to his heart.
Prince Andrew dared not do so.
Prince Andrew stood over the child.
Prince Andrew gazed at the child's head.
Prince Andrew gazed at the child's little arms and legs under the blanket.
Prince Andrew heard a rustle behind him.
A shadow appeared under the curtain of the cot.
Prince Andrew did not look round.
Prince Andrew still gazed at the infant's face.
Prince Andrew listened to the infant's regular breathing.
The dark shadow was Princess Mary.
Princess Mary had come up to the cot with noiseless steps.
Princess Mary lifted the curtain.
Princess Mary dropped the curtain behind her.
Prince Andrew recognized Princess Mary without looking.
Prince Andrew held out his hand to Princess Mary.
Princess Mary pressed the hand.
Prince Andrew said 'He has perspired.'
Princess Mary said 'I was coming to tell you so.'
The child moved slightly in his sleep.
The child smiled.
The child rubbed his forehead against the pillow.
Prince Andrew looked at Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's luminous eyes shone more brightly than usual.
Princess Mary's eyes had tears of joy.
Princess Mary leaned over to Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary kissed Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary slightly caught the curtain of the cot while kissing.
Prince Andrew and Princess Mary made a warning gesture to each other.
Prince Andrew and Princess Mary stood still in the dim light beneath the curtain.
They did not wish to leave the seclusion where the three were shut off from all the world.
Prince Andrew was the first to move away.
Prince Andrew ruffled his hair against the muslin of the curtain.
Prince Andrew said 'Yes, this is the one thing left me now.'
Prince Andrew said it with a sigh.
Pierre was admitted to the Masonic Brotherhood.
Soon after his admission, Pierre went to the Kiev province.
The Kiev province had the greatest number of serfs for Pierre.
Pierre took with him full directions he had written down.
The directions were for Pierre's own guidance as to what he should do on his estates.
When Pierre reached Kiev, he sent for all his stewards to the head office.
Pierre explained to his stewards his intentions and wishes.
Pierre told his stewards that steps would be taken immediately to free his serfs.
Pierre told his stewards that until then serfs were not to be overburdened with labor.
Pierre told his stewards that women nursing their babies would not be sent to work.
Pierre told his stewards that assistance would be given to the serfs.
Pierre told his stewards that punishments would be admonitory and not corporal.
Pierre told his stewards that hospitals would be established on all the estates.
Pierre told his stewards that asylums would be established on all the estates.
Pierre told his stewards that schools would be established on all the estates.
Some stewards listened with alarm.
Those stewards supposing the words meant the young count was displeased with their management.
Those stewards supposing the words meant the young count was displeased with embezzlement of money.
Some stewards after their first fright were amused by Pierre's lisp.
Some stewards after their first fright were amused by new words they had not heard before.
Some stewards simply enjoyed hearing how the master talked.
The cleverest stewards understood how they could best handle the master for their own ends.
The chief steward was among the cleverest stewards.
The chief steward expressed great sympathy with Pierre's intentions.
The chief steward remarked that besides these changes it would be necessary to go into the general state of affairs.
The general state of affairs was far from satisfactory.
Count Bezúkhov had enormous wealth.
Count Bezúkhov had an income said to amount to five hundred thousand rubles a year.
Pierre felt himself far poorer than when his father had made him an allowance of ten thousand rubles.
Pierre had a dim perception of the following budget.
